Company: UNUM
Agency: Washington State Department of Labor & Industries
Info Source: Contained in data obtained on May 15, 2017 in response to an open records request.

Company: UNUM Life Insurance Company of America
Private Litigation Case Title: Mogel et al v. UNUM Life Insurance Company of America

Company: Unum Life Insurance Co.
Description: O'Neill, Finnegan & Jordan, a Boston insurance brokerage firm, and Unum Life Insurance Co., a subsidiary of UnumProvident Corp., agreed to jointly pay $1.3 million in settlement of allegations that Unum's commission payment to OFJ when arranging state contracts was illegal. The announcement did not indicate how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided equally between hem.

Company: UnumProvident Corporation
Description: UnumProvident agreed to pay $15.5 million in restitution and $1.9 million in penalties to resolve an investigation of deceptive practices in its compensation of brokers and consultants in connection with the sale of group insurance products.

Company: UnumProvident Corporation
Description: UnumProvident agreed to pay $15 million as part of the settlement of multistate allegations that it inappropriately denied claims for benefits under individual and group long-term disability insurance policies.

Company: Unum Group
Unum Insurance Co.
Description: Metropolitan Life Insurance, Prudential Insurance Co. and Unum Insurance Co. agreed to pay a total of $1.1 million in settlement of allegations by three California District Attorneys that they paid illegal rebates to a brokerage firm to obtain business.

Company: Unum Life Insurance Company of America et al.
Description: Unium Life Insurance Company of America, Provident Life and Accident Insurance Co., and The Paul Revere Life Insurance Co. agreed to pay an $8 million civil penalty and $598,503 in costs in settlement of allegations they committed multiple insurance violations related to avoiding paying legitimate health insurance claims.

Company: UnumProvident Corp. et al.
Description: UnumProvident Corporation, Provident Life and Accident Insurance Company and Unum Life Insurance Company of America agreed to pay $700,000 in costs in settlement of allegations they violated insurance regulations by failing to disclose details of compensation and contingent compensation for the Producer representing the policyholder.

Company: Unum Life Insurance Company of America
Unum Life Insurance Company of America
Unum Life Insurance Company of America
Provident Life and Accident Insurance Co.
Info Source: NORTH CAROLINA FINES PROVIDENT LIFE & ACCIDENT $80,000, Bestwire, August 15, 2000 (via Nexis).

Company: UNUM LIFE INSURANCE COMPANY
Unum Life Insurance Company Of America
Description: Fine levied for accepting applications for long term care from producers who were not in compliance, failure to timely file, and failing to verify that all of its agents had completed the required long term care insurance education before permitting them to sell long term care policies. RCW 48.83.13...
Agency: Washington State Office of the Insurance Commissioner

Company: Unum Life Insurance Company Of America
Description: Fine levied for selling group long term care policies on contract forms that had not been amended and approved to comply with changes in the long term care insurance laws and using policy contract forms that were not properly amended to reflect changes to the long term care insurance laws. RCW 48.1...
Agency: Washington State Office of the Insurance Commissioner

Company: Unum Life Insurance Company Of America
Description: Company fined $7,000 for issuing letters to policy holders with the unapproved language. RCW 48.05.140(1); RCW 48.18.100(1); RCW 48.18.100(5).
Agency: Washington State Office of the Insurance Commissioner

Company: First Unum Life Insurance Company of America and Paul Revere Life Insurance Company
Description: The Superintendent of Financial Services announced that First Unum Life Insurance Company of America and Paul Revere Life Insurance Company would pay a $1.8 million penalty to New York State for violations of  DFS's Cybersecurity Regulation that caused the exposure of a substantial amount of sensitive, non-public, personal data belonging to its customers, including thousands of consumers nationally and hundreds in New York.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services
